newsitem.title: ESTONIA: CENTRAL BANK CRITICISES AUDIT REPORT.
newsitem.headline: CENTRAL BANK CRITICISES AUDIT REPORT.

text.p: The Estonian central bank said on Thursday said that a recent report by the state audit office on the bank's activities had harmed the institution and it rejected the document's findings.
The central bank was making the findings of the report public after several leaks in the local media last week.
"As a whole, the state audit visit harmed the Estonian central bank," central bank president Vahur Kraft told a news conference.
The audit criticised the central bank for making loans that were too risky, losing money in the buying and selling gold and lending money to employees at low rates of interest.
Bank vice-president Peter Lohmus said that the audit did not assess the central bank's effectiveness according to its strategic goals or internationally acknowledged methods.
"To assess effectiveness, it should proceed from compareable data, comparing it with other central banks or similar economic institutions in a similar environment," Kraft said.
The report criticised the central bank despite the fact that it made its largest profit in 1996, which was 186 million kroons, compared to 83.6 million kroons in 1995.
Central bank assets grew to 9 billion kroons in 1996 from 7.76 billion kroons in 1995.
"We see clear trends which show the effectivness of our job," Lohmus added.
